attachments.title: TikTok Inks Deal With WWE For 30 New Wrestler Accounts, Entrance Music Licensing - Tubefilter
attachments.text: WWE is body-slamming onto TikTok today, with a new pact that will see the wrestling media purveyor -- which counts 1 billion followers across all of its social channels globally -- launch various new channels on the Bytedance-owned, short-form video app.  The channel launch coincides with WWE’s annual Tables, Ladders & Chairs pay-per-view wrestling event, which features the aforementioned objects as weapons and is slated for this Sunday. On its new TikTok channel, the WWE will share moments from in-ring matches as well as backstage action via exclusive daily content. In the first day of its launch, the channel has already accumulated upwards of 110,000 followers. In addition to its flagship WWE account, the organization is launching accounts for more than 30 wrestling personalities -- including both current competitors and storied vets like 'Stone Cold' Steve Austin, The Undertaker, Ultimate Warrior, Becky Lynch, John Cena, and Sasha Banks (pictured above). And as part of the deal, each wrestlers’ original entrance music will also become available to other TikTokkers for use in their videos as part of TikTok’s music library.  WWE is body-slamming onto TikTok today, with a new pact that will see the wrestling media purveyor -- which counts 1 billion followers across all of its social channels globally -- launch various new channels on the Bytedance-owned, short-form video app.
attachments.fallback: Tubefilter: TikTok Inks Deal With WWE For 30 New Wrestler Accounts, Entrance Music Licensing - Tubefilter

attachments.title: For The First Time, YouTube Consumption Will Inform The 'Billboard 200' Albums Chart - Tubefilter
attachments.text: Beginning next year, the Billboard 200 chart -- which tracks the nation’s most popular albums of the week based on a number of factors, including traditional album sales, and other digital-equivalent metrics -- will incorporate video and audio data from YouTube in making its calculations. The move marks a notable adjustment by the iconic charts tabulator and media brand, as video becomes an increasingly vital component of music consumption today. The changes will take effect with the chart dated Jan. 18, which will reflect album sales and streams clocked between Jan. 3 and Jan. 9. That said, not every video will be incorporated into the Billboard rankings -- only officially licensed videos, meaning that user-generated videos will be excluded. In addition to YouTube, the Billboard 200 charts will henceforth integrate licensed video data from other platforms as well.  The Billboard 200, which formerly served as a pure sales chart, began integrating audio streams in Dec. 2014. Today marks the first time that licensed video content will factor in as well. In addition to the flagship Billboard 200 chart, YouTube and other video data will similarly be integrated into Billboard's genre-specific album charts, including 'Country', 'R&B/Hip Hop', 'Latin', and more.  Beginning next year, the Billboard 200 chart -- which tracks the nation’s most popular albums of the week based on a number of factors, including traditional album sales, and other digital-equivalent metrics -- will incorporate video and audio data from YouTube in making its calculations.
attachments.fallback: Tubefilter: For The First Time, YouTube Consumption Will Inform The 'Billboard 200' Albums Chart - Tubefilter

attachments.title: Instagram Launches AI Tool That Warns Users Before They Post Potentially Offensive Captions - Tubefilter
attachments.text: Instagram is today rolling out a new tool as part of its anti-bullying efforts -- this time in a bid to crack down on potentially bullying photo and video captions. The feature will notify users when their captions may be considered offensive, as determined by artificial intelligence tech that has been developed by Instagram, which marks against other captions that have been reported for bullying. The notification is intended to make users pause and reconsider their captions, with the opportunity to edit, though it does not physically prevent them from posting. The feature is rolling out today in select countries, Instagram says, and will become available globally in coming months.  “Results have been promising, and we’ve found that these types of nudges can encourage people to reconsider their words when given a chance,” Instagram wrote in a blog post. “In addition to limiting the reach of bullying, this warning helps educate people on what we don’t allow on Instagram, and when an account may be at risk of breaking our rules." Instagram is today rolling out a new tool as part of its anti-bullying efforts -- this time in a bid to crack down on potentially bullying photo and video captions.
attachments.fallback: Tubefilter: Instagram Launches AI Tool That Warns Users Before They Post Potentially Offensive Captions - Tubefilter

attachments.title: MrBeast Drops Trailer For Finale Of ‘Last To’ Series, With $1 Million Grand Prize - Tubefilter
attachments.text: MrBeast, the uber-generous YouTube star -- and Streamy 'Breakout Creator' winner -- whose real name is Jimmy Donaldson, has released the trailer for his latest video, which may be one of his biggest stunts to date. The clip, dropping on Thursday at 4 pm ET, boasts a familiar -- yet compelling -- premise: Donaldson has placed $1 million in single dollar bills inside of a large glass case. Four four contestants will then have to place their hands on the case, with the last one touching the glass at the end of the challenge being crowned winner, and taking home the money.  The video is the fifth part in a series of videos that Donaldson began rolling out in November. Each of those clips featured a similar 'last to...' premise and produced a finalist, who will then go on to compete for the $1 million finale. Previous contests included Last To Fall (into a pool of water while balanced on a rope), Last To Stop Swinging, Last To Leave The Toilet, and Last To Stop Biking. Donaldson culled contestants from his fanbase, with eligibility open to anyone who purchased merch or followed him on Instagram. (The full rules to the sweepstakes are available here, and episodes two and four of the series appear to have been sponsored by browser extension Honey). MrBeast, the uber-generous YouTube star -- and Streamy 'Breakout Creator' winner -- whose real name is Jimmy Donaldson, has released the trailer for his latest video, which may be one of his biggest stunts to date.

attachments.title: These Are The 10 Most-Viewed YouTube Ads Of The Year - Tubefilter
attachments.text: In addition to the myriad year-end lists that YouTube released surrounding its annual Rewind venture, the platform has today unveiled its most-viewed ads. The so-called year-end YouTube Ads Leaderboard serves to recognize the most creative ads that viewers chose to watch between Jan. 1 and Dec. 1 -- as determined by a YouTube-derived algorithm that factors in both organic and paid views, as well as watch time and audience retention.  Amazon once again nabbed the top spot for an Alexa spot, for which it also topped last year’s chart. (Last year's winner was another Alexa spot for the 2018 Super Bowl dubbed Alexa Loses Her Voice). Furthermore YouTube noted that many of the ads on this year's list hailed from the commercial bonanza that is the Super Bowl. Six of the top ten ads originated as Super Bowl spots, YouTube noted -- signalling that marketers were able to extend the return on their investment beyond the big game.  In addition to the myriad year-end lists that YouTube released surrounding its annual Rewind venture, the platform has today unveiled its most-viewed ads.

attachments.title: After Inking Multiyear Endorsement Deal, Ninja Unveils First Adidas Sneakers - Tubefilter
attachments.text: In August, Tyler 'Ninja' Blevins inked a historic deal Adidas, becoming the first pro gamer to sign with sportswear giant.  At the time, Blevins’ wife and manager, Jessica Blevins, tweeted an image of a Ninja-branded Adidas jacket, signalling that co-designed sportswear could be coming down the pike. Yesterday, however, Blevins unveiled his first drop with the company -- a sneaker that's been dubbed the Time In Night Jogger. The name of the shoe refers to the fact that Blevins put an enormous amount of time into becoming one of the world’s foremost gamers. Priced at $150, according to Kotaku, it will drop on New Year’s Eve. "To kick off my collaboration with Adidas, I wanted to create a shoe that honors everyone who puts in the hard work to perfect their craft,” Blevins said in a statement on the Adidas website. “Everyone who knows what it’s like to sacrifice for their passion. Everyone who puts the time in. Whether you’re on hour 1 or 1,000 of your journey, this shoe is for you.”  In August, Tyler 'Ninja' Blevins inked a historic deal Adidas, becoming the first pro gamer to sign with sportswear giant.
attachments.fallback: Tubefilter: After Inking Multiyear Endorsement Deal, Ninja Unveils First Adidas Sneakers - Tubefilter

attachments.title: Australian Millionaire Seeking Personal Instagram Photographer, At $55,000 Salary - Tubefilter
attachments.text: In a not-so-surprising turn amid today’s Insta image-obsessed climate, an Australian millionaire is making international headlines for a job post calling for a personal social media photog. Matthew Lepre, the 27-year-old founder of ecommerce training course Ecom Warrior Academy, is putting out the call for a full-time photographer who would travel the globe with him and snap photos for his two Instagram accounts, which count a combined 213,300 followers. Lepre is offering a $55,000 annual salary to the job recipient, with a job description -- appropriately shared on Instagram -- that states that the gig does not require any prior experience, and that Lepre will cover travel expenses, training, and equipment. The chosen candidate will also be able to bring a friend on the road. To be fair, the listing reads more like an Instagram contest -- and a publicity ploy -- than an actual job listing, though it undoubtedly speaks to the importance of honing a carefully-crafted social presence in today’s business sphere. To be eligible for the job, aspiring photographers must be following Lepre and his business' Instagram accounts, tag a friend on the job announcement post, and then submit their details at this link (which appears to be down at press time). The winner will be announced on May 31. In a not-so-surprising turn amid today’s Insta image-obsessed climate, an Australian millionaire is making international headlines for a job post calling for a personal social media photog.
attachments.fallback: Tubefilter: Australian Millionaire Seeking Personal Instagram Photographer, At $55,000 Salary - Tubefilter

attachments.title: Mixer Sees 149% Year-Over-Year Jump In Hours Watched, But Is Still Far From Challenging Twitch’s 9.3 Billion - Tubefilter
attachments.text: Mixer’s recent bold and likely expensive business moves--poaching Twitch’s top star, Ninja, along with a handful of other major streamers--drew attention and new eyeballs to the growing platform, which experienced significant growth this year and appears to be making a (small) dent in Twitch’s streaming space domination. attachments.title: Fifa, product placement and the future of ads in video games
attachments.text: Against the backdrop of a tumultuous year in the video game industry, the Fifa franchise has been consistently stoic in its success. There are big opportunities for marketers to speak to a burgeoning fanbase that is passionately devoted to the game. However, are marketers fully embracing the advertising formats gaming has to offer?
attachments.fallback: The Drum: Fifa, product placement and the future of ads in video games

attachments.title: ‘We're not activists’: Timberland distinguishes its eco focus in first ‘truly’ global push
attachments.text: Timberland is committing to planting 50m trees by 2025, a mission that will fuel the content of its newly-aligned marcomms teams in the years to come. But it's an equal focus on fashion and profit that its leadership hopes will distinguish such an eco-led purpose from those of its outdoor competitors.
attachments.fallback: The Drum: ‘We're not activists’: Timberland distinguishes its eco focus in first ‘truly’ global push

attachments.title: JD.com challenges Starbucks’ attempt to own the ‘third space’ with Seven Fun launch
attachments.text: <http://JD.com|JD.com> has launched a lifestyle store concept in Beijing as part of a strategy to own people’s ‘third space’, beyond home and work.
